title: What’s that ringing in your ears? - Marc Fagelson

multiple-choice.question: What is tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of hearing loss that affects people's ability to hear external sounds.

options.label: B
options.text: The perception of a noise like ringing, buzzing, hissing, or clicking that occurs without any external source of sound.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of ear disorder that affects the middle ear.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of brain disorder that affects people's ability to process sounds.

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many people worldwide experience tinnitus?
Where do the nerve signals that produce tinnitus sounds come from?
What is the primary function of the background neural activity in the auditory system?

options.label: B
options.text: To establish the neural code for silence

options.label: C
options.text: To distinguish between silence and sound

multiple-choice.question: What is subjective tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of tinnitus that is caused by external factors

options.label: B
options.text: A type of tinnitus that is associated with ear disorders

options.label: C
options.text: A symptom associated with practically every known ear disorder

options.label: D
options.text: A condition that has inherently negative consequences

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of sound therapy in treating tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the loudness of the tinnitus sound

options.label: B
options.text: To mask the tinnitus sound with other noises

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the stress associated with tinnitus

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate the tinnitus sound completely

multiple-choice.question: What is informational masking in sound therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of soothing, complex auditory signals to distract the brain from the tinnitus sound

options.label: B
options.text: The use of sounds with the same frequency as the patient's tinnitus to occupy the neurons that would otherwise deliver the tinnitus signal

options.label: C
options.text: The use of loud noises to increase the loudness of the tinnitus sound

options.label: D
options.text: The use of silence to reduce the stress associated with tinnitus

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between tinnitus and PTSD, insomnia, anxiety, and depression?

options.label: A
options.text: Tinnitus can cause PTSD, insomnia, anxiety, and depression

options.label: B
options.text: Tinnitus can exacerbate the symptoms of PTSD, insomnia, anxiety, and depression

options.label: C
options.text: Tinnitus has no relationship with PTSD, insomnia, anxiety, and depression

options.label: D
options.text: Tinnitus can cure PTSD, insomnia, anxiety, and depression

title: What if you stopped drinking water?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why every living organism requires water to survive?

options.label: B
options.text: To carry nutrients and hormones through the body.

options.label: D
options.text: To consume it consistently every day.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of an adult's body is made up of water?
What is the main function of the Thirst center of the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect changes in blood pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: To monitor the amount of sodium and other substances in the body.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body if it is unable to satisfy thirst?

options.label: B
options.text: The body becomes dehydrated and the initial signs are a dry mouth and darker urine.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the brain when the body is dehydrated?
What happens to the body after a day or two without fluids?
What is the main reason why victims of dehydration may become delirious?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of a lack of oxygen.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of a lack of food.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of a lack of sleep.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body after 3 to 5 days without water?

options.label: B
options.text: The body begins to shut down its organs and eventually the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of all Earth's water is fresh?
What is the main solution to the global water crisis?

options.label: B
options.text: Relying on individuals to understand and contribute to the crisis.

title: What can DNA tests really tell us about our ancestry? - Prosanta Chakrabarty

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of our genome is shared among all humans?
How much of our DNA is utilized by commercial DNA tests?
What process occurs when a sperm or egg goes from a cell with 46 chromosomes to a sex cell with only 23 chromosomes?
Why do two sisters' chromosomes differ from each other?

options.label: B
options.text: Because recombination occurs uniquely in each sex cell

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the numbers of DNA inherited from ancestors as you go further back in generations?
Why is it difficult to say certain things with 100% certainty when looking for traces of our ancestry in our DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the complexity of the human genome

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the way we inherit DNA

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the information available for testing

multiple-choice.question: What is the assumption behind commercial DNA tests when they compare genetic markers between individuals?

options.label: A
options.text: That the shared markers indicate ancestors from the same place

options.label: B
options.text: That the shared markers indicate a common disease

options.label: C
options.text: That the shared markers indicate a common trait

options.label: D
options.text: That the shared markers indicate a common environment

multiple-choice.question: Why are many indigenous peoples barely represented in commercial DNA tests?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have not had their genomes sequenced

options.label: B
options.text: Because they do not have access to the tests

options.label: C
options.text: Because they do not have a significant impact on the results

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not of European descent

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the 2% Neanderthal in a person's DNA?

options.text: It indicates that the person is 2% Neanderthal

options.label: B
options.text: It indicates that the person has Neanderthal ancestors

options.label: C
options.text: It indicates that the person is 100% Neanderthal

options.label: D
options.text: It indicates that the person has no Neanderthal ancestors

multiple-choice.question: Why is it possible for a person to be both 100% French and 2% Neanderthal?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the 100% French and 2% Neanderthal are accounting for different things

options.label: B
options.text: Because the 100% French and 2% Neanderthal are accounting for the same thing

options.label: C
options.text: Because the 100% French and 2% Neanderthal are not related

options.label: D
options.text: Because the 100% French and 2% Neanderthal are not part of the same genome

title: Why do we have belly buttons?

multiple-choice.question: What is something that every single person on Earth has?
Why do animals that grow inside their mothers have belly buttons?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are born with them

options.label: B
options.text: Because they need something to breathe air

options.label: C
options.text: Because they need an umbilical cord to carry oxygen and nutrients

multiple-choice.question: What is the umbilical cord?

options.label: A
options.text: A flexible tube that carries oxygen and nutrients from the mother to the baby

options.label: B
options.text: A flexible tube that carries waste from the baby to the mother

options.label: C
options.text: A flexible tube that carries food from the mother to the baby

options.label: D
options.text: A flexible tube that carries water from the mother to the baby

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the umbilical cord after a baby is born?

options.label: A
options.text: It stays attached to the baby

options.label: B
options.text: It falls off after a few weeks

multiple-choice.question: Why do chimpanzees and gorillas have belly buttons that look like ours?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they grow inside their mothers

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a similar digestive system

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are closely related to humans

multiple-choice.question: What happens to animals that lay eggs, like birds and reptiles?

options.label: C
options.text: They are born with umbilical cords

options.label: D
options.text: They do not have belly buttons

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a belly button?

options.label: D
options.text: To mark the spot where the umbilical cord was attached

multiple-choice.question: Why do animals have belly buttons, but robots do not?

options.label: A
options.text: Because animals are living things and robots are not

options.label: B
options.text: Because animals grow inside their mothers and robots do not

options.label: C
options.text: Because animals need belly buttons to breathe air

options.label: D
options.text: Because animals need belly buttons to eat food

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the last bit of the umbilical cord that is left on a baby's belly?

options.label: B
options.text: It falls off after a few weeks

multiple-choice.question: Why is it hard to find the navels on really furry animals like pet dogs?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they do not grow inside their mothers

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not closely related to humans

options.label: D
options.text: Because their fur covers their belly buttons

title: When is a pandemic over?

options.label: C

options.text: The amount of time it takes for a vaccine to be developed

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most effective way to contain the spread of the virus

options.label: C

options.label: C
